Cliveâ€™s Album of the Year, 1986

  • Clive Murray

    Rock guitarist and gentleman adventurer from a land before time.

Clive Murray

10 November 2017 â€¢ 5 min read

1986. I was 12, and had yet to develop any taste in music, so as before this is all retroactive. This is also as far back as Iâ€™m going with the whole â€œ1 winner and 5 runners-upâ€ thing. My original idea was to try and go right back to the year of my birth, 1974, but I just canâ€™t find enough music that I like from all of those years. What weâ€™ll have after this is a digest format with the best one of the year, and possibly an honourable mention or two. So now you know.

1986 was designated the International Year of Peace by the UN. Good-oh. Kodak were beaten out of the instant camera game by Polaroid, the first PC virus started to spread, Voyager 2 met Uranus (snigger), Space Shuttle Challenger tragically exploded 73 seconds after launching, Pixar, Halleyâ€™s Comet popped by, Mir, hailstones weighing 1kg killed 92 people in Bangladesh (yes, really), the Chernobyl disaster happened killing over 4000 people and forcing 350000 out of their homes, Hands Across America, Maradona and the â€œHand of Godâ€, New Zealand decriminalised homosexual sex (between men â€“ lesbian sex was never criminalised in NZ), Andrew married Fergie, Phantom opened in London, the M25 was opened, The Simpsons were created and the first commercial 3D printer was sold.

Those cashing in their chips and going for a long lie down included Phil Lynott, the git behind scientology, Jimmy Cagney, Wallis Simpson, Cliff Burton and Cary Grant.

Arriving presumably not on a one-in-one-out basis were Matt Heafy, Jessica Ennis-Hill, Gemma Arterton, Ophelia Lovibond, Charlotte Church, Lady Gaga, R-Patz, Megan Fox, Rafael Nadal, Shia LaBeouf, LiLo, Usain Bolt, Florence Welch, Emilia Clarke, Oscar Pistorius, Amir Khan, John Snow (Kit Harington) and Ellie Goulding. There were of course many more, but those are the ones Iâ€™ve heard of.

As mentioned my 1986 list is completely retroactive â€“ in 1986 I think all I was listening to was Dire Straits, Queen and Jean-Michel Jarre (not that thereâ€™s anything wrong with any of that).

Some notable omissions that didnâ€™t make the list: Bon Jovi â€“ Slippery When Wet, Metallica â€“ Master of Puppets, Iron Maiden â€“ Somewhere in Time, It Bites â€“ The Big Lad in the Windmill and Beastie Boys â€“ Licensed to Ill. Those are all good, but imho, these are betterâ€¦

Honourable mentions

Megadeth - Peace Sellsâ€¦ But Whoâ€™s Buying?

My metal awakening was still a few years away when this came out, but looking back itâ€™s an absolute classic and a shortlist must-have. Worth the price of admission several times over for the title track alone, yet some may say â€œHow can you include this and not Master of Puppets? Are you a mental?â€ The simple fact is I prefer Megadeth to Metallica â€“ always have. Iâ€™ll give you that there are a couple of missteps on this album (WTF is â€œI Ainâ€™t Superstitiousâ€ doing on here?) but when itâ€™s good, itâ€™s impeccable. Top track: â€œPeace Sellsâ€

Queen - A Kind of Magic

I was even in the Queen fan club for a few years. At the time I had no idea what AIDS was, or what gay really was, and had no idea that Freddie was not that long for this world. I just loved their music, or at least what I had of it. Itâ€™s only recently Iâ€™ve gone back to the early proggy albums and discovered a whole bunch of weird, but then that was the 70s for you. This, the unofficial soundtrack to one of my favourite 80s films â€œHighlanderâ€, has a couple of mawkish moments but again â€“ when itâ€™s good, itâ€™s absolutely amazing. See â€œOne Visionâ€, the title track, and the splendid â€œGimme the Prizeâ€ for details. (I know his name.) Top track: â€œOne Visionâ€

David Lee Roth - Eat 'Em and Smile

When DLR quit Van Halen, the rock world must have wondered what the hell he â€“ or they â€“ were going to do next. Well, Diamond Dave recruited the hottest musicians available (Steve Vai, Billy Sheehan, Gregg Bissonette, Brett Tuggle) and punted out a solo album that combined Daveâ€™s trademark lounge schtick with some of the most blistering virtuoso rock tunes ever made, still to this day. Indispensable, though hardly flawless. Top track: â€œLadiesâ€™ Nite in Buffalo?â€

Paul Simon - Graceland

This was the first album I ever owned that wasnâ€™t a kids album like Mr. Men or something. My late Grandma bought me the tape of it for Christmas or birthday, probably in 1987, and it went into my tape player and hardly came out for months. I still love it. Thanks, Grandma. Top track: â€œThe Boy in the Bubbleâ€

Van Halen - 5150

So we know what Roth did when he quit Van Halen, but what did the rest of his erstwhile band do? They recruited a new singer and kept on trucking, thatâ€™s what. This was Sammy Hagarâ€™s first album with VH and it was one of the first two rock/metal albums lent to me as part of my metal education by my best friend at the time, Nick Redfearn (the other was Eliminator by ZZ Top). Having never heard VH with Roth at the time, I was spared the inevitable comparisons and potential disappointment that a lead singer swap can engender, and loved it from the get go. Still do. (The following album OU812 is a total crock, though.) Top track: â€œGood Enoughâ€

And the winner isâ€¦

Peter Gabriel - So

I simply will never get bored of this album, as long as I live. I adore everything about it. From the swelling intro to â€œRed Rainâ€ right to the closing repeated phrases of â€œThis Is the Pictureâ€, there is not a sound on this album that I am not eternally in love with. As an aside, it is also forever linked in my mind to the Clive Barker book â€œImajicaâ€, which I was reading when I first discovered this album. I recommend them for simultaneous use.

I was never into Genesis of any era, so only really first heard of Gabs when â€œSledgehammerâ€ stormed up the charts and appeared on Top of the Pops with its splendid video, and then noticed him again when the duet â€œDonâ€™t Give Upâ€ achieved similar success, but it was a few years later that I picked up the album and properly explored its groove, which I found to be righteous (helped along massively by the extremely groovy Tony Levin on bass, of course).

A pop classic, 9 well-crafted songs, and a voice with a range and depth of emotion that Iâ€™ve rarely heard. Lovely stuff.

Top tracks: â€œMercy Streetâ€, â€œRed Rainâ€, â€œDonâ€™t Give Upâ€

Turkey of the year

Poison - Look What the Cat Dragged In

Oh good god.
